desc: when a feature is developed purely because it will look good in a demo.
when you deploy to production without testing.
when you are tasked to make changes to legacy code that lacks tests, is highly coupled and behaves in mysterious ways.

when you attempt to forestall mistakes during coding by moving at a snail's pace, producing, double-checking, and re-triple-checking lots of paper artifacts, before producing any actual working software. In essence, being so afraid of making mistakes that you end up not producing anything at all.
when you come to hate working on something so much that it inspires a surge of productivity that leads to completion. Most projects that involve this methodology include a procrastination phase.
when you make the code as hard to understand as possible, so that they won’t be able to replace you.
when two halves of one team work on the same problem starting at opposite ends, hoping that they’ll meet in the middle.
when management believes that the only path to improved developer productivity is imposing arbitrary, unrealistic deadlines.
when you write code to increase your visibility with management, let things break so that you can be the hero that fixes them and generally work on things that lead to a corner office asap.
when everybody pretends there is a method for what’s being done, and that things are going ok, when in reality, things are a mess and the process is on the floor.
when the driving force behind your efforts is to make sure that when the shit hits the fan, your are not the one to blame.
when the biggest jerk in the team makes all the big decisions.
when you ignore requirements and pick implementation approaches based on how good they look good on your resume.
